title: Sticky / setuid / setgid
content:
Special permission bits

  • sticky bit (on directories): users can delete only their own files
  • setuid: program runs with file owner privileges
  • setgid: program runs with group privileges (or directories inherit group)

Typical example: /tmp

/tmp often has the sticky bit set.

ls -ld /tmp
# Look for a 't' in the permissions (e.g., drwxrwxrwt)

Setting sticky bit (example)

mkdir -p ~/unix-cli-practice/sticky-demo
chmod 1777 ~/unix-cli-practice/sticky-demo
ls -ld ~/unix-cli-practice/sticky-demo

Use special bits carefully; setuid/setgid are security-sensitive and typically managed by package/system admins.
